value.title: IBM's new 2-nm chips have transistors smaller than a strand of DNA
value.excerpt: In a shining example of the inexorable march of technology, IBM has unveiled new semiconductor chips with the smallest transistors ever made. The new 2-nanometer (nm) tech allows the company to cram a staggering 50 billion transistors onto a chip the size of a fingernail.

value.title: States push back against use of facial recognition by police
value.excerpt: Law enforcement agencies across the U.S. have used facial recognition technology to solve homicides and bust human traffickers, but concern about its accuracy and the growing pervasiveness of video surveillance is leading some state lawmakers to hit the pause button.

value.title: Missouri woman discovers WWII military device in her backyard
value.excerpt: (CNN)A Missouri woman found more than weeds poking out of the soil in her yard this weekend. Pamela Coffey told CNN that she was just about to take lunch break from doing yard work on Saturday when she spotted a small metal object jutting out from the soil under her feet.

value.title: From Coral Reefs To Assembly Lines, Computer Vision Gives New View On How To Work Smarter
value.excerpt: Once a thing of science fiction, the vast uses for computer vision technology are now clear. Advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) over the past 10 years have helped scientists develop computer vision technology – an AI application that allows computers to “see” their surroundings and make these visual inputs actionable with 99% accuracy.

value.title: Samsung Bespoke Jet Bot AI Robot Vacuum Cleaner launched in Korea
value.excerpt: Samsung has unveiled the Bespoke Jet Bot AI Robot Vacuum Cleaner designed to significantly improve home cleaning duties. The robot vacuum cleaner features enhanced capabilities for object recognition and adopts artificial intelligence (AI) technology which significantly improves the performance as well.

value.title: False facial recognition sends innocent New Jersey man to jail
value.excerpt: New Jersey police arrested an innocent man on unlawful possession of a weapon, resisting arrest and aggravated assault charges after he was falsely identified by facial recognition technology. value.title: False facial recognition sends innocent man to jail

value.title: China Publishes Draft Security Standard on Facial Recognition
value.excerpt: On April 23, 2021, the National Information Security Standardization Technical Committee of China published a draft standard (in Chinese) on Security Requirements of Facial Recognition Data
